name: NHL 25 Offensive Strategy Tree
description: Canonical offensive strategy tree using ONLY NHL 25 in-game options: Defend Lead, Conservative, Standard, Aggressive, and Full Attack. Each option includes strengths, weaknesses, and score/matchup usage rules.

notes: All offensive strategy names must match NHL 25 UI EXACTLY.
Matchup outputs must only use these five options.
Offensive Strategy is the global mindset that combines with Forecheck, Neutral Zone, and sliders.

Defend Lead.label: Defend Lead
Defend Lead.description: Lock-down mentality focused on protecting the scoreboard more than generating offense. Prioritizes safe plays, low-risk exits, and strong puck management.
strengths: Reduces risk of bad turnovers in dangerous areas.
Supports defensive structure and lead protection.
Ideal for closing out games in the 3rd period.
weaknesses: Reduces offensive pressure and shot volume.
Can invite sustained pressure if used too early.
Makes it harder to answer quickly if opponent scores.

score_state: Leading by 1 or 2 in the 3rd period.
Final 5–8 minutes of a game when protecting a lead.
After an icing or long shift when you need to reset safely.
avoid_when: Tied in the 1st or 2nd unless under heavy pressure.
When your team is outshooting the opponent badly and you want to keep momentum.

Conservative.label: Conservative
Conservative.description: Low-to-moderate offensive risk level with focus on safe entries, smart dumps, and puck support. Less aggressive than Standard but not full turtle.
strengths: Good puck security with some offensive presence.
Helps stabilize games when momentum is against you.
Pairs well with strong goaltending and structure-first teams.
weaknesses: Can limit scoring chances vs weaker opponents.
May miss chances to fully exploit mismatched lines or tired defenders.
Not ideal when chasing the game.

score_state: Nursing a 1-goal lead in early or mid-game.
When your team struggles with turnovers and you want to settle things down.
avoid_when: Facing a poor defensive team you should be pushing harder against.

Standard.label: Standard
Standard.description: Balanced offensive mindset that mixes controlled entries, cycles, and opportunistic attacks. This is the baseline setting for most situations.
strengths: Versatile and stable in most matchups.
Easy to adjust up or down to Aggressive or Conservative as game flow changes.
weaknesses: Not specialized for full shut-down or all-out attack.
May feel too passive vs very weak opponents.
Does not maximize comeback potential when trailing.

score_state: Default starting point before adjusting to how the game feels.
avoid_when: Severely outshooting a weak opponent (might want Aggressive).
Desperately needing goals late (Full Attack or Aggressive better).

Aggressive.label: Aggressive
Aggressive.description: Higher-risk mindset focused on pressure, quick attacks, and sustained offensive zone time. Encourages more pinches, layered forecheck, and higher shot volume.
strengths: Increases shot volume and offensive zone time.
Good for tilting the ice vs weak defenses.
Can break down tired or slow opponent D cores.
weaknesses: Higher risk of odd-man rushes against.
Can tax your defense and goalie if execution is sloppy.
Dangerous if your team is already losing the transition battle.

score_state: Tied late in games when you want the win.
Trailing by 1 in the 2nd or early 3rd.
Vs slower or weaker defensive teams you can pressure.
avoid_when: Already heavily out-chanced on the rush.
Protecting a lead late in the 3rd.
When your defense or goalie is struggling badly.

Full Attack.label: Full Attack
Full Attack.description: Maximum offensive risk. Everyone is joining the rush, pinches are frequent, and the priority is generating goals immediately, even at the cost of defense.
strengths: Ideal when you need multiple goals late.
Works well when opponent is already sitting back in a shell.
weaknesses: Very high risk of odd-man rushes and breakaways against.
Can blow a close game wide open in the wrong direction.
Taxing on fatigue and goalie workload.

score_state: Trailing by 2+ late in the 3rd period.
Desperation mode with goalie pulled or about to be pulled.
Playoff elimination games when you must score.
avoid_when: When your goalie is already under siege.

notes: Use Standard while building the lead, then shift to Conservative or Defend Lead.
In final 5–8 minutes, Defend Lead is preferred, especially with strong goaltending.
Standard is the default balanced choice.
Conservative vs stronger teams or on the road.
Aggressive if you sense the opponent is weak or gassed.
Aggressive when down 1 or when there is still time.
Full Attack only when time is short or you are down by 2+.

integration_notes: Offensive Strategy works together with forecheck choice and trap slider.
For example: Aggressive + 1-2-2 Aggressive + higher trap level creates a full pressure identity.
Defend Lead + 1-2-2 Passive + lower trap level creates a clock-kill, safe structure.
